events.title: 29th Athens Cycling Tour
events.description: The Athens Cycling Tour is back for its 29th edition...
events.fullDescription:
For twenty-nine years, the Athens Cycling Tour has reclaimed the city's streets for two-wheeled exploration, transforming car-dominated avenues into peaceful cycling routes and reminding Athenians that their city belongs to people, not just automobiles. On October 19th, the tradition continues as thousands of cyclists take to the streets for the annual celebration of pedal-powered mobility.

Athens's relationship with cycling remains complicated. Despite Mediterranean weather perfect for year-round riding, cycling infrastructure has lagged behind other European capitals. Bike lanes remain inconsistent, drivers often view cyclists as obstacles rather than fellow road users, and car culture dominates transportation planning. Yet the Athens Cycling Tour persists, growing year after year, proving that demand for cycling-friendly Athens continues to build.

The annual tour does more than provide recreation—it demonstrates possibility. When thousands of cyclists roll through central Athens on traffic-free streets, it shows residents what car-free urban space feels like. Children ride alongside parents, experiencing their city from a new perspective. Recreational cyclists and serious riders share the same route, united by two wheels and forward motion. For a few hours, Athens feels like Amsterdam or Copenhagen, showing what could be rather than what is.

The route typically showcases Athens's diverse neighborhoods, offering views you'd never appreciate from a car window. You'll pedal past ancient sites and modern developments, through residential areas and commercial districts, experiencing the city's topography in your legs and lungs. Athens's hills provide challenge, but the tour accommodates various fitness levels, prioritizing participation over competition.

Beyond individual experience, the Athens Cycling Tour serves as collective advocacy. Each participant becomes a rolling demonstration that Athens can embrace cycling culture. Politicians notice when thousands of voters demand better infrastructure. Businesses notice when cycling events attract customers. Each year's tour builds momentum for permanent change—more bike lanes, better connectivity, safer streets for everyone.

The event begins at 4:00 PM on October 19th, with free participation open to all ages and abilities. You'll need your own bicycle (rentals are available throughout Athens), basic safety equipment including a helmet, and enthusiasm for experiencing your city differently. Registration details and route information are available through This is Athens website.

Whether you're a daily cyclist advocating for better infrastructure, a recreational rider seeking community, or someone curious about experiencing Athens by bike, the 29th Athens Cycling Tour welcomes you. Join thousands of fellow cyclists, reclaim the streets, and help pedal Athens toward a more sustainable, livable future.

events.title: Juergen Teller: you are invited
events.description: German photographer Juergen Teller's first-ever exhibition at Onassis Ready...
events.fullDescription:
Juergen Teller doesn't take photos the way other fashion photographers do. Where the industry demands polish and perfection, the German-born artist delivers rawness, humor, and uncomfortable intimacy. His images have graced the pages of i-D, W Magazine, and countless Vivienne Westwood campaigns, yet they often look nothing like traditional fashion photography. Models appear unglamorous, celebrities look awkward, and luxury goods are presented with deliberate anti-glamour. It's fashion photography that questions fashion itself.

"you are invited" marks Teller's first major exhibition at Onassis Ready, the contemporary art space in Ag. Ioannis Rentis that has quickly established itself as one of Athens' most important cultural venues. The exhibition arrives at a perfect moment, as Teller's influence on contemporary photography has never been more apparent. His aesthetic, once considered shocking, now defines an entire generation's understanding of what fashion imagery can be: personal, political, playful, and profoundly human.

The show brings together works spanning Teller's career, from his early breakthrough campaigns to recent projects that continue pushing boundaries. You'll encounter his famous portraits of Kate Moss looking decidedly unglamorous, celebrities photographed in mundane settings, and images that blur the line between high art and snapshot photography. Teller's genius lies in making the viewer question what they're looking at: is this fashion? Art? Documentary? The answer is always yes, all three, and something more.

Onassis Ready provides an ideal setting for this encounter with one of photography's most provocative voices. The industrial space in Rentis has become Athens' go-to venue for challenging contemporary art, offering exhibitions that don't play it safe. The neighborhood itself, once purely industrial, is quietly transforming into a cultural destination, and Onassis Ready sits at the heart of this change.

Teller's work rewards close looking and repeated viewing. These aren't images designed to be scrolled past on Instagram; they demand you slow down, look carefully, and consider what fashion photography can be when it refuses to follow the rules. The exhibition includes vintage prints, recent work, and potentially unpublished images that offer fresh perspectives on Teller's singular vision.

For anyone interested in photography, fashion, or contemporary art, this exhibition is essential viewing. Teller has fundamentally changed how we think about fashion imagery, and seeing his work in person reveals details and nuances impossible to appreciate on screen. The opening is October 19th at 18:00, and the show will run for several weeks. Make the journey to Rentis; it's absolutely worth it.

events.title: Red Snapper
events.description: British trio performs acid jazz, trip-hop, and psychedelic surf music
events.fullDescription:
Red Snapper emerged from London's mid-1990s experimental music scene as something genuinely unusual: a trio that could satisfy jazz heads, club kids, and post-rock enthusiasts simultaneously. David Ayers on guitars, Ali Friend on double bass, and Richard Thair on drums/programming created a sound that defied easy categorization, blending acid jazz, trip-hop, dub, and what they cheekily termed "psychedelic surf music." On Sunday, October 19, 2025, at 9:00 PM, this influential British group performs at Gazarte Roof Stage, offering Athenians a rare opportunity to experience their genre-defying live show against the backdrop of Gazi's industrial-chic architecture.

What made Red Snapper distinctive wasn't just their instrumental virtuosity, though all three members are formidable musicians. It was their ability to bridge seemingly incompatible worlds: acoustic bass meets electronic programming, jazz improvisation meets club rhythms, organic instruments meet studio manipulation. Their 1996 debut album "Prince Blimey" became an underground classic, influencing countless producers and bands while earning comparisons to everyone from Portishead to Tortoise to dub pioneers like King Tubby. Tracks like "Hot Flush" and "The Sleepless" demonstrated how electronic and acoustic elements could intertwine seamlessly, creating music that felt both timeless and futuristic.

The trip-hop era that birthed Red Snapper has long passed, but their music hasn't dated. Instead, it sounds prescient, anticipating contemporary electronic music's embrace of live instrumentation and jazz's ongoing dialogue with beats and technology. Seeing them live reveals dimensions that recordings can only hint at, especially Friend's hypnotic double bass work, which provides both melodic foundation and percussive drive, and Ayers' textured guitar work, which ranges from ambient swells to funky scratches.

Gazarte Roof Stage, perched atop one of Gazi's converted industrial buildings, offers spectacular views across Athens while providing excellent sound quality. The €20-€30 ticket price is reasonable for international touring acts of Red Snapper's caliber and reputation. The venue's location in Gazi, Athens' nightlife and cultural district, means the evening can extend well beyond the concert, with numerous bars, clubs, and restaurants within walking distance.

This concert appeals to multiple generations: those who discovered Red Snapper in the '90s and new listeners curious about the roots of contemporary electronic-jazz fusion. It's a Sunday night show, making it perfect for those who want cultural stimulation without sacrificing Monday morning functionality.

Experience Red Snapper's liquid bass lines and psychedelic grooves at Gazarte Roof Stage. This is music for heads, hearts, and hips simultaneously. Get your tickets now and witness British experimental music royalty in Athens' coolest converted industrial venue.

events.title: Sunn O)))
events.description: American experimental drone metal duo performs immersive live show
events.fullDescription:
Describing a Sunn O))) performance to someone who hasn't experienced it firsthand feels impossible. This isn't a concert in any conventional sense. It's a physical phenomenon, a sonic ritual, an encounter with sound so overwhelming that it transcends music and becomes something closer to a natural force. The American drone metal duo of Stephen O'Malley and Greg Anderson create music that you don't just hear; you feel it in your chest, your bones, your entire body.

Formed in Seattle in 1998, Sunn O))) (pronounced "sun") took inspiration from Earth's pioneering drone metal and amplified everything: the volume, the distortion, the glacial pacing, the sheer crushing weight of sound. Over nine studio albums, they've collaborated with avant-garde composers, metal legends, and noise artists, always pushing toward more extreme sonic territories. Their music exists at the intersection of metal, minimalist composition, noise art, and something indefinable that exists beyond genre entirely.

Live performances are where Sunn O))) truly come alive. The stage fills with fog machines creating an impenetrable wall of smoke. The musicians, dressed in robes like some doom-metal monastic order, stand nearly motionless as they coax earth-shaking frequencies from amplifiers turned to volumes that defy belief. Each note sustains for minutes, creating harmonic overtones that seem to vibrate in impossible spaces. It's meditative and punishing simultaneously, a test of endurance that becomes transcendent for those willing to surrender to it.

Athens gets this rare experience at Gagarin 205, the capital's premier venue for heavy music and alternative rock. Located on Liosion Street, Gagarin has built its reputation on bringing the world's most uncompromising artists to Greek audiences, and Sunn O))) represent perhaps the most extreme booking on that continuum. The venue's powerful sound system and devoted audience make it the perfect setting for this sonic assault.

Come prepared: earplugs are not optional, they're essential. Sunn O))) concerts routinely exceed 120 decibels, reaching levels that can cause hearing damage without protection. But don't let that scare you off. Experiencing this music at these volumes, feeling the air move with each bass note, watching the fog swirl in patterns created by pure sound—it's unlike anything else in contemporary music.

Tickets are €30-35, and this show will sell out. Sunn O))) tour infrequently, especially in Southern Europe, making this Athens appearance a genuine event for anyone interested in experimental music, heavy sound, or simply experiencing the absolute extremes of what live performance can be. Doors at 21:00, October 19th. Prepare yourself for something extraordinary.
